Award.AwardTitle: Differentiated Professional Development: Building Mathematics Knowledge for Teaching Struggling Learners

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project under the direction of the Education Development Center is creating and studying a two year professional development model for middle school mathematics teachers with an emphasis on teaching struggling math students in the areas of fractions and rational numbers. There are three components to the PD for teachers: online modules, professional learning communities, and face-to-face workshops. There are four online modules 1) Fraction sense: concepts, addition, and subtraction, 2) Fraction multiplication and division; 3) Decimal and percent operations; and 4) Integer sense, including concepts and operations. Each module is one week long. There are common sessions and special emphasis ones depending on the needs of the teacher. The project addresses three research questions: 1) To what extent do participating teachers show changes in their knowledge of rational numbers and integers, pedagogical knowledge of and beliefs about instructional practices for struggling students and abilities to use diagnostic approaches to identify and address student difficulties?; 2) To what extent do students of participating teachers increase their mathematical understanding and skill?; and 3) To what extent do students of participating teachers show positive changes in their attitudes toward learning mathematics?

In the first year of work on the professional development program, fifty-five teachers will test the initial components of the differentiated modules. In years two and three an additional 160 teachers will participate in the professional development and research to test efficacy of the professional development model. In addition to this testing, twelve teachers will be selected for intensive case studies. Teacher content knowledge, pedagogical content knowledge, and attitudes will be assessed by various well-validated instruments, and changes in their classroom practice will be assessed by classroom observations. Effects of the teacher professional development on student learning will be evaluated by analysis of data from state assessments and by performance on selected items from NAEP and other standardized tests.

This project will result in a tested innovative model for professional development of mathematics teachers to help them with the critical challenge of assisting students who struggle in learning the core concepts and skills of rational numbers and integers. Deliverables will include the on-line modules, materials for workshop and professional learning community work, new research instruments, and research reports.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The case that has been made for differentiating instruction for students, also applies to professional development (PD) for teachers. Teachers vary greatly in their own prior content knowledge, experiences and skills, but PD programs typically use a one-size-fits-all approach. There is a pressing need for models, approaches, and examples of ways to differentiate PD to address teachers’ wide range of professional learning needs and interests. In response, the Differentiated Professional Development: Building Math Knowledge for Teaching Struggling Learners (DPD) project created three differentiated courses on rational number and integer concepts for teachers and a general model for differentiating PD that can be applied to other content areas.

For the DPD courses, the three main learning goals for teachers were to: 1) build a deep and flexible understanding of key mathematics concepts from the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) for rational numbers and integers; 2) gain knowledge of student misconceptions and build diagnostic skills for identifying students’ understandings, strengths, and needs, and 3) acquire instructional strategies for building students’ conceptual understanding, addressing the needs of struggling learners, and making lessons more accessible while maintaining the integrity of the mathematics content. The project’s central design challenge was how to create PD that would support all participants in reaching these goals, while differentiating the learning experiences to address teachers’ varied needs.

In response to this challenge, the project staff explored ways to differentiate the PD, developing and refining a model. The DPD model has three main components: 1) core activities that address essential content and provide a common experience for participants; 2) choice points that allow teachers to select activities and individualize their learning; and 3) self-assessment opportunities that allow teachers to reflect on their knowledge and make choices for next steps to match their learning needs. Using this model, we created and tested three PD courses for general education/mathematics teachers and special educators in grades 4-7.

The project staff used an iterative development process that involved cycles of design, testing, and revision to create the PD courses. A separate team of researchers who were not involved in the development or facilitation of the courses conducted formative and summative research. The formative phase focused on teachers’ use of and feedback on the courses, particularly the differentiated activities. For the summative phase, the research team conducted field tests of the three courses in which they used a mixed methods approach to determine the extent to which the program achieved its goals for the participating teachers.

Findings from the field test of the fractions course are reported here because it was the most extensive one, involving four cohorts with a total of 104 teachers from 16 districts. In this field test, participants took three pre-post program instruments: 1) a Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching (MKT) measure developed by the Learning Mathematics for Teaching (LMT) project at the University of Michigan; 2) a Classroom Video Analysis (CVA) Assessment (Kersting, Givvin, Sotelo, & Stigler, 2010) which required participants to watch eight video segments from fraction lessons and write responses to a prompt for each one; and 3) a Pedagogy measure with likert-scale questions on teachers’ comfort and preparedness for teaching fractions, for using diagnostic practices, and for addressing the fraction difficulties of struggling learners. Pre-post increases were statistically significant for all three measures. Two limitations of this study are the lack of a control group and the self-report nature of the Pedagogy instrument.

The project had a direct impact on 188 teachers (mathematics teachers, general educators, and special educators) from 21 districts who participated in the courses. These teachers serve about 4,700 students each year. Each course provided about 40 hours of PD and included assignments to apply formative assessment probes and instructional strategies with students.

To disseminate the project’s work, the project staff used multiple channels to reach the target audiences of mathematics education leaders, PD developers/providers, and teachers. Dissemination activities included seven presentations at national conferences, including the National Council of Supervisors of Mathematics (NCSM) and Learning Forward. Two journal articles were accepted for publication:

  • Brodesky, A., Fagan, E., Tobey, C.R. and Hirsch, L., “Moving Beyond One-Size-Fits-all PD: A Model for Differentiating Professional Learning for Teachers.” NCSM Journal of Mathematics Education Leadership, Spring 2016, pp. 20-37.
  •  Fagan, E., Tobey, C.R., and Brodesky, A., “Targeting Instruction with Formative Assessment Probes.” Teaching Children Mathematics, October 2016, Volume 23, No. 3, pages 146-157.

The first article describes the DPD model and provides examples, guiding questions, and planning tools to support educators in applying the ideas to differentiate their PD programs. The second article focuses on a strategic process for using formative assessment probes to gather and interpret evidence of students' mathematical understandings and misconceptions and then targeting instruction to address identified needs. Sample probes and resources are available on the project’s website: edc.org/accessmath.
